faqs.question: Is pet insurance worth it for a Miniature Schnauzer?
faqs.answer: Yes. Mini Schnauzers are prone to pancreatitis, diabetes, and bladder stones—all requiring ongoing care. Insurance helps manage both emergency costs and chronic condition expenses.

faqs.question: Why do Mini Schnauzers get pancreatitis?
faqs.answer: They're genetically prone to high blood fat (hyperlipidemia), which increases pancreatitis risk. A low-fat diet helps prevent episodes, but some dogs still develop it. Treatment can be expensive.

faqs.question: Are Miniature Schnauzers prone to diabetes?
faqs.answer: Yes—more than most breeds. It typically appears in middle age and requires lifelong insulin injections and monitoring. Insurance helps cover ongoing costs.

faqs.question: What causes bladder stones in Mini Schnauzers?
faqs.answer: They're prone to certain stone types due to genetic factors. Special diets can help prevent recurrence, but some dogs need surgical removal. Insurance covers both surgery and prescription food (with some plans).

faqs.question: Should I feed my Mini Schnauzer a special diet?
faqs.answer: A low-fat diet is recommended to reduce pancreatitis risk. If your dog develops stones, your vet may prescribe a therapeutic diet. Some insurance plans cover prescription food.
